text:
really, really good recipe with the following tweaks:  i tried to keep the florets as uniform in size as possible to accomplish even cooking.  i added the parsley at the start to let the flavor bake in.  i also added 3/4 tsp. onion powder.  i covered and cooked at 400 for 20 mins, then added bread crumbs and a fair amt. of romano chz and broiled for abt. 5 mins uncovered (my oven has a low and high broiler setting--i went the low route) and it was delicious.  great way to make cauliflower and will save this recipe!

text:
This is now my favorite way to prepare cauliflower!  Nice to see a healthy way to perk up cauliflower - I usually just steam it, and I try to avoid the cheese sauces that so frequently go along with cauliflower.  This is easy and delicious.  The only change I would make is to just toss the oil and garlic with the cauliflower in a bowl instead of the bag, as some of the garlic bits got stuck to the inside of the bag and it was a pain to scrape them out.  Otherwise a perfect, healthy recipe!  It is even delicious cold (couldn't stop picking at it after dinner...)  Thank you for sharing!

This was unlike any cauliflower I have ever eaten-truly special and unique. Whether it's the roasting aspect, or the addition of Parmesan cheese, or the combination of the two, this is a memorable dish, which is saying a lot since after all, this is just cauliflower! text:
I thought this recipe was soooo good. I love cauliflower and like finding new ways to prepare it that don't involve a heavy, dairy-based sauce. This was fantastic. I only used about 1/4 c of parmesan cheese, which seemed like enough. I used Kraft Parm Plus so it has garlic, basil, and some other stuff in it and it was VERY tasty, but I think regular parmesan would be just fine. I also added about 1/4c. of italian breadcrumbs. This was so easy and tasty, I will definitely make this again. Oh, after reading about some people haveing problems with burning garlic, I kept the dish covered with foil for the first half of cooking. And I didn't find it undercooked at all; I thought it was perfectly cooked.

NOTE: This makes an EXCELLENT cold salad! Just substitute it in place of your potatoes or toss it with other chopped veggies and a good italian dressing. It's SO good.

text:
I was looking for a recipe for the frozen cauliflower I had on hand, but I tried this even though it called for fresh. I used about 1.5 TBS olive oil and 4 large cloves of garlic. I added the whole bag of cauliflower frozen which congealed the oil, but I was still able to get it all covered. It was ready in less than 20 minutes and was very good and very easy. I'll try it with fresh next time to see if it is worth the difference in time and money. Update: Yes, the fresh is worth the extra time and money! Love it.

text:
We were going to have cauliflower today but I wanted something different.  I used this recipe exactly as written (well, more garlic :-), and didn't read reviews first.  I will definitely roast this veggie more often; thanks, Shellery!  (I enjoy it raw and steamed, and mashed, too) Now, after having read ALL 615 reviews, quickly skipping over all of those that added enough extras to make a casserole, I agree that I'll skip the bag next time...to avoid having to scrape the insides for minced garlic!  I agree that maybe some disappointing results had to do with the freshness of the cauliflower. I think part of the attraction of this recipe is the ease of preparation with no pre-cooking required, for us, anyway. I agree it's important to have all pieces about the same size. I "sliced" the florets and they really browned beautifully!  I used a 9x13 Pyrex dish, uncovered, and had *some* burned garlic after stirring since some pieces escaped to the sides of the pan, unnoticed.  (Not a problem since I had added extra!!) I used olive oil to grease the pan and had no problems with cleanup.  I can't comment on leftovers because we didn't have any!   We'll enjoy variations now and then but the original recipe is delicious!  Try this, especially if you already like cauliflower :)  and garlic :)

We really enjoyed this. However, I didn't use a whole head of cauliflower as I had already bought florets.  What I found to be a problem was that the garlic and parmesan cheese both scorched before the cauliflower was completely done.  This whole dish actually only took about 25-30 minutes to complete.  I'll make it again, but will have to really watch the progress so it doesn't burn.

text:
I actually think this recipe is better (and easier) with just olive oil, sea salt and a generous sprinkling of garlic powder.  Also, I always use frozen cauliflower; just cook it a bit longer. Wonderful with broccoli, too!  Oh, one more thing:  I always roast broccoli/cauliflower at 400 degrees instead of 450.  Also, there's no need to grease your casserole dish or use a plastic bag to mix this up.  Just put your veggies in the (preferably glass) pan, pour on the oil and seasonings, toss everything together and cook.

I thought this was a fantastic recipe for cauliflower.  I personally love cauliflower, but hubby isn't as fond, so I decided to try this one out.  I used about 6 cloves of garlic, baked at 425 (was cooking something else too), cooked uncovered for about 25 mins and then covered for another 15. text:
Really excellent!  I was not a "cooked" cauliflower fan at all but wanted to add some new veggie's to my family meals and decided to give this a go.  EXCELLENT!  I use more garlic and crushed red pepper.  The amount of olive oil stated is plenty.  I toss this whole thing in the dish I'm baking it in and it tosses fine.  The cooking time may be a little off.  I tend to cook for a bit longer but I think it comes down to how well done you like your vegetables.  Mine was still crunchy with the stated time.  I went another 10-12 minutes and got it to my level of doneness.  This one is definitely a keeper and is the only way I'll be preparing cauliflower from now on.  Thank you!

text:
My son said this was mighty tasty! I didn't even know he liked cauliflower. I roast cauliflower frequently and don't understand why everyone wants to cover it to steam it. Part of the roasting process is to carmelize the vegetable and have it all nice and browned. At 450 with minced garlic the garlic does tend to get burned a little, but it gave great flavor to the cauliflower. I tossed in a bowl like I always do. After adding the cheese and dried (no fresh) parsley I did broil for a few minutes, but I don't think it is a necessary step if you have roasted uncovered. The cheese will melt from the heat of the cauliflower, unless it is to get it browned a little. Very nice change for us from cajun seasoned cauliflower. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
Okay ... I just made this for with supper tonight.  Husband is not home yet, but I wanted elements of the meal ready to go for when he gets back.  It might not make it that long.  Notes, though:  you don't need to cover it when cooking - you want a roast to it and covering it will more steam it.  Enjoy the roast.  Don't add bread crumbs - you want this to be a vegetable roast and nothing more.  Leave it simple and enjoy the flavor of the cauliflower and garlic.  The light flavor of the cauliflower with the roasted garlic (which sweetens it) combine beautifully enough.  The parmesan adds a light element with a tiny bit of salt, so don't salt it too much in the beginning.  I did find that I didn't want the whole 1/3 cup of cheese, but my cauliflower head was small, so you may want to use more than I did.

Don't tweak ... let the flavors shine through!

text:
Those of you saying to "cover it" are out of your minds.  If you want to steam the cauliflower, go ahead and cover it...but if you want to roast it (as the recipe name "ROASTED Garlic Cauliflower" indicates), don't!  That delicious carmel-colored browning that happens is not burning.  That's what happens to veggies when you roast them - for the love of God, let it happen!  This recipe is perfection.   Thank you!

text:
Thanks for such a great recipe!  I have gotten so I make this all the time and have tried various techniques & ingredients.  Our favorite is:  3-4 T of extra virgin OO, 6-8 cloves of chopped garlic, about a tsp of garlic powder, salt, ground pepper, 1/3 c parmesan, I mix that all in a zip lock baggie and let maranaide at least an hour.  I do it at 450 for 20 - 25 minutes until it browns a little.  Then I pull it out & wait for the rest of my meal to finish cooking.  Just before serving I sprinkle with extra sharp cheddar cheese & parsley & throw in the broiler for couple of minutes until nice & hot & cheese is crunchy on the pan.  I have had a lot of teenagers mothers call me and ask me for this recipe because their kid came home and raved about it.  P.S.  My farvorite is to do this on my pampered chef cookie sheet stone so no need to pre-greese.  If that's being used for something else I use a regular cookie sheet & put down a piece of tin foil otherwise cleanup can be a real pain.

text:
I had never tried cauliflower (unbelievable, I know), and it was so delicious prepared this way!  I didn't change a thing as far as the ingredients go.  I lined my pan with foil because I always end up having to soak my pans for weeks after roasting vegetables, haha.  I also covered the pan with foil while cooking it... I think that's why my cauliflower came out soft and not a bit crunchy as some of the other reviewers have mentioned.  Broiling it at the end was such a nice touch.  The cauliflower was slightly browned and the cheese was melty... I love this!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I did this on the bbq.  Just put cauliflower, oil and garlic all mixed into a foil packet.  BBQ about 10 minutes on one side, flip and cook 10 minutes more.  Open packet and sprinkle with parmesan, salt, pepper and parsley.  Close packet for 5 minutes to let cheese melt.  Excellent, it smells as good as it tastes.  This is the best way to have cauliflower.

I made this last night. It was wonderful. And easy. 
It baked in the oven while I did other supper things. Then it had to sit on the counter (covered with foil) while the broiler was busy with salmon fillets (I took it out of the oven while it was a bit undercooked).
I mixed the cheese and seasonings in with the cauliflower rather just leaving it set on top and stirred the dish a couple times while it was broiling.
My husband and teen-aged son loved.
A great way to fix an under-utilized veggie.

text:
Very, very good!  I added some extra garlic because I am a garlic freak, mixed the parsley with the oil mixture and, before broiling, added about 1/4 cup of buttered Italian bread crumbs to the top.  I did bake the cauliflower in a covered casserole but I cooked it for about 40 minutes because I like the cauliflower soft and juicy.  It WAS that and my husband and I alone polished off a very large cauliflower --- which I served with baked sweet potato and pan-grilled chicken breasts.  A relatively low calorie, healthy and delicious meal.  I will be preparing cauliflower in this manner again and again.  Thank you for sharing!

text:
I have been making cauliflower this way for years and it is simply the best! Roasting really brings out the flavor of the cauliflower. I would suggest turning the temp down to 400 and roasting for 20-25 minutes. Also, make sure you cover your baking dish with aluminum foil! This will prevent your garlic for scorching and make your veggies more tender.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe tonight for the third time, and it was PERFECT-so delicious that I am going to double it for a company dinner party next month.  I cut the cauliflower into SMALL florets.  I steamed the cauliflower for 4 minutes.  I then mixed the cauliflower in a bowl with the garlic, olive oil, fresh  parsley, and I added 1/2 chopped red onion, a few baby carrots that I peeled  with a potato peeler, some fresh oregano and a squeeze of fresh lemon juice.  I cooked it covered at 400 until it was soft enough (at least a half hour).  We like it soft, but that is a personal preference.  Then I added parmesan cheese and whole wheat bread crumbs and broiled for 2 minutes uncovered.  My broiler is extremely hot. Yummy !!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We absolutely loved this.  The darker it got, the tastier it got.  We did some with and some without the parmesan at the end and it was good both ways.  If your broiler gets too hot you can toast finely grated parmesan in a non stick pan over med-low heat.  Shake or gently stir often so it browns evenly.  It's super yummy.
A lot of reviews suggest covering the dish - that completely defeats the purpose, it won't be roasting.  For this recipe you want the cauliflower to turn dark.  The black edges were my favorite part!

text:
This is the only way I cook cauliflower. Family who didn't like cauliflower loved this recipe. I bake 15 minutes at 425, turn over the cauliflower, bake 15 mins. add cheese, bake 10 mins.  I do not cover as I like the cauliflower to brown a bit rather than steam.   I make this even when I'm cooking for one as it reheats nicely. I use fresh shredded Parmesan cheese in place of grated.

OH MY GAWD...this was the FIRST time I ever tried to cook cauliflower and let me tell you this is GOOD...I didn't even know if I really liked cauliflower...but I DO NOW!!! This was easy and VERY flavorful. The only thing I think I did wrong (so I will share my ignorance with the world so that hopefully I will be the only one that does it) was to use that type of grated Parmesan Cheese that you buy off the grocery store shelf, and even with that this was still DELICIOUS. Didn't change a thing!!! My only suggestion is the serving size be adjusted from 6 to 1...because 1 person can easily eat the ENTIRE thing this is so good. I will be cooking this at least once per week.

text:
This was delicious.  Note:  You DO NOT need to cover while roasting.  Just make sure your rack is in the middle of the oven, and turn the cauliflower after about 10 minutes.  I had cut my florets in half, because they were quite large.  Because of this, I reduced the roasting time by 5 minutes.  After adding the parmesan and parsley, I put the oven rack on the top and broiled for about 1-2 minutes.  Perfect!  Will make this again.  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
Like others I found the heat far too high.  As well, I put a lid on. Followed the advise of one reviewer to use a bowl but then found that the garlic pieces were burning.  My suggestion is to infuse the oil with the garlic in a pan, strain the garlic out before using oil. If that is adding one more step then perhaps just garlic powder could be used, (although I'm not a fan of powder it does have its uses). It will be a matter of tweaking between the heat, lid, and garlic.

This recipe is really fantastic. I added Kosher salt to the oil and garlic to give it more flavor. Reggiano, this was awesome, almost like scampi. (I know that sounds weird, but the extra virgin olive oil and Parm. Regg., yum.) Next time I'm going to add a little crushed red pepper in with the oil and garlic. This recipe spiced up a dinner of turkey sandwiches.

Display Name:
Christy Cooks

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/501992.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I roast cauliflower all the time, but thought I'd try this recipe because of the high reviews. I didn't need nearly that much oil, and think it would be way too greasy if I had used the stated amount. The flavors were nice together, but I agree with the reviewers who said that by the time the cauliflower was tender the garlic was starting to burn a bit. My initial feeling was to add the garlic at the halfway mark, but decided to follow the directions (after all, this was much easier), and am sorry I did. I also didn't understand the need to use a bag, so I just mixed the ingredients in a bowl and poured them onto a foil lined baking sheet. I may combine these flavors again, but will probably add the garlic further into the cooking process. Finally, I found 450* to be a bit too high, 400 worked very well for me.

text:
I made this exactly as described, except didn't bother with the whole bag-mixing step, just mixed everything right in the baking pan.  I also didn't bother broiling at the end, just cooked it a little longer (maybe 40 minutes total).  The cauliflower was perfectly browned without being burnt.  And, I used sea salt and dried parsley flakes instead of fresh parsley.  Will definitely be making this again, although I may try to cut down to 2 tbs oil to cut out some calories.  This was hands-down the best cauliflower I've ever had, although it does make it a little less healthy than my normal plain, steamed cauliflower.

text:
I think I make this at least once a week now. My family and I enjoy this very much.  I followed the recipe except for the temperature/time.  I have a convection bake oven so I cooked at 425 for 10 mins, removed and stirred then put back in for another 10 mins.  I removed from the oven stirred and sprinkled with shredded parm and put back in the oven for another 5 mins.  This was so delicous.  My husband usually doesn't like anything with cheese but it is such a mild flavor enhancer that he didn't notice and still loved them. I don't think I can eat cooked cauliflower any other way again.  Thanks so much for the recipe.

text:
Fantastic! I skipped the cheese and it was tasty without it. I followed the advice of many and put the florets in a bowl and drizzled the oil and garlic in and mixed it by hand. I spread it on a cookie sheet and baked at 400. I used purple cauliflower because it was so cool looking at the store! (Unlike most vegetables that lose their unusual color when cooked, the purple got darker when roasted!) Really great! Kids even liked it.

text:
This was such a simple, and different, way to cook cauliflower. I usually just steam it, but I wanted to try the new purple cauliflower and didn't want to steam it, since the nutrients are so water soluble. I followed other reviewers suggestions, and covered the casserole dish for the first 20 minutes, then uncovered, added cheese and broiled. Next time I use purple cauliflower, I'll cut back my cooking time since it cooks so much faster than the regular. Will definitely be using this recipe again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Oh, my goodness, this was delectable.  Hard to beleive it's a vegetable!  This will become a regular in the meal rotation and for special meals.  I let it get a bit brown, and the "crunchies" were delicious.    Be prepared that they shrink in size by probably about 50%. Keep the pieces on the big side for nicer presentation. I had about 1/3 of a head for 2 of us and we would have liked a bit more.    I LOVE cheese...so it pains me to say this, but it really doesn't need the parmesan.  I forgot to put it on before serving, and probably won't bother to next time, either.    Oh, don't be worried about the large amount of oil...a lot of it sticks to the bag and there is a lot in the bottom of the baking dish...I can't imagine very much is actually on the florets.    Top it off with a sprinkling of sea salt...:-)

text:
I made this last night and everyone around the table loved it. I used garlic powder instead of fresh garlic because I was concerned it would overbrown and make the dish bitter. I also added some broccoli because I had it on hand. Omitted the parsley because I didn't think it was necessary. There was no need to waste a plastic bag, either. Just dump all the ingredients into the pan and mix with your hands. This is a terrific winter side dish!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Cauliflower can put off alot of water which can drown the other flavors.  I've done this similarly in a pan using olive oil, and a bit of butter.  Salt the florets, toss to coat, turn down heat to medium low and cover.  When tender but not mushy, Drain off excess water leaving just a little wet in pan; Add garlic (fresh or roasted), parmesan and just a sprinkling of bread crumbs, retoss and heat for just a few more minutes.  Everyone loves this.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I changed this recipe a little... 
On my first try : I only used 2 tbs of Parmesan cheese, I added 1 pinch of red pepper flakes, 1/4 cup italian bread crumbs and 1 tbs of dried parsley (didn't have it fresh). I didn't grease the casserole dish. I placed the olive oil, garlic, salt, pepper and red pepper flakes in the dish and tossed in the cauliflower. Topped it with bread crumbs, Parmesan cheese and parsley after cooking for 25 min., and broiled on low until golden brown. My bf who doesn't like vegetables liked this recipe.
The second time: I used 2 tbs olive oil, 0.5 tbs pesto, 1 tbs balsamic vinegar and I omitted the parmesan and parsley.
I preferred my second attempt at this recipe!

text:
Wow, and I didn't think I liked Cauliflower.  We got some from our CSA, so I thought I'd try to cook it.  I used this recipe since it was one of the few on the site with little or no dairy.  In fact, I omitted the parmesan cheese, and it still came out fabulously.  I may actually purposely buy cauliflower now.  This was delicious and EASY!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674146.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious!  I made a couple of changes that made it a little healthier, and this is definitely making it into my rotation of dinners.  First of all, I only added less than 1/4 cup of parmesan and a little less oil and I didn't grease the pan.  I also ommitted all of the salt.  Also, I just mixed it all together before I put it into the oven covered and stirred it once during cooking.  This made it super simple and the taste was wonderful.  I have also made this when you add the cheese and parsley on top at the end and broil it and it was good but it didn't reheat well the next day.  Also, for the calorie and sodium difference I would much rather do it my way.  This tastes very indulgent without a lot of calories, almost like garlic mashed potatoes!

text:
A Keeper!  So simple and it went so well with my roast beef which I was cooking at 450 degrees for 25 min. and then lowered to 375.  I took the cauliflower out after 25 min. - let it sit.  When the roast beef was done to our liking I took that out and popped the cauliflower with the cheese mixed in (used another reviewer's suggestion for that- it turned out well) and broiled it while I was making the gravy.  The garlic flavor in the cauliflower was super!  That and the mashed potatoes with gravy made a nice, quick Sunday meal.

text:
Cooked cauliflower is something I rarely make, unless I also make cheese sauce.  But, much to our surprise, we loved this!  I used the method described in the original recipe and it came out perfect; no burning.  The only thing I did differently was to skip the plastic bag for tossing the cauliflower with oil/garlic, and just tossed in the 13x9 pan with my hands (which already smelled garlicky).  That way I didn't lose any of the delicious garlic bits. Thank you for sharing!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3648295.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious! I rinsed the cut-up cauliflower and let it dry really well, covered a baking sheet with foil, spread out the cauliflower, drizzled with just enough olive oil to moisten, added salt, herbes de provence and fresh cracked black pepper, mixed it all up with clean hands and roasted at 400 degrees for 30 minutes, stirring about halfway and keeping an eye on it so it gets browned and crisps up on the outside. We like a crisper, more well-done cauli. I always burn garlic when I try to add it to roast vegetables, so I left it out, but would use granulated garlic if I was going for some garlic flavor. Try this - you will fall in love with cauliflower!

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been making cauliflower like this for years and absolutely love it when prepared this way. To make it Paleo-friendly, I've omitted the cheese but added extra garlic to boost up the flavor and add to the browning. I also use this recipe for making broccoli and Brussel  sprouts. I prefer to bake the florets on a cookie sheet for 10-15 minutes at 350F, then broil them for 5 minutes or less, turning florets as needed. Even my husband, who only eats cauliflower with cheese sauce (LOTS of cheese sauce) ate them. I ate the leftovers as snacks the next day - yummy and VERY filling!

country:
None
text:
We loved this!  A friend of mine told me to use a garlic press for the garlic (instead of using minced garlic,) and nothing on my dish scorched or burned at all.  Next time I would skip the bag and make this in a bowl as I could never get all of the juicy bits out of the bag.  Also I must have had a big head of cauliflower and could not use a casserole dish but used a large cookie sheet instead.  For the cooking time, my same friend advised me to cook this in (3) 10 minute intervals, shaking or stiring up the cauliflower each time, adding the parmasan cheese in the last 10 minutes (I also cooked it quite close to the top of the oven just under the top rack at 450 degrees as stated...truely ROASTED CAULIFLOWER!!... not steamed at all, I did not cover this.)  It couldn't have turned out more perfect. I'll be making this ALOT!  Thank you!!

text:
I wish I hadn't read all the reviews first and cooked as originally written.  That being said, what I did was change recipe slightly by using 2 Tbs reg olive oil and 1 Tbs jalapeno infused olive oil. I lowered the heat to 425 and covered the dish for the first 20 min.  it was undercooked, so stirred and left uncovered for another 10.  stirred and let cook another 5.  FINALLY got the little roasted spots I was looking for.  Threw on some parmesan and it was pretty amazing.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I made this tonight.  I was looking for a recipe that I had all the ingredients for and could use up a head of cauliflower that I bought.  This was delicious. I did not have the parsley, but will use next time.  
I cut the florets as uniformly as possible, and put them in a large bowl.  I then used my garlic press to press the garlic into 3 Tbs olive oil and poured it over them.  I mixed them well and then spread them in a pan to roast at 400 degrees for 25 minutes.  I put the Parmesan over them and left them in the oven until it was melted and browned.
My 14 yo looked at the recipe and said "gross", but after one bite he said "this is delicious!"  Will make again and again!  Thanks!

Roasted cauliflower is my family's favourite cooked vegetable which I've made for years.  We do two things differently.  Instead of salt and pepper, I use a bit of onion salt. This version is as big hit with kids who think they don't like vegetables.  We all love this, and it is healthy too!

text:
My oh my, what a woderful way to eat cauliflower!  I could eat this everyday!  I didn't have parsley and didn't use salt & pepper either.  I tossed the rest in a bowl, extra garlic of course, and arranged the pieces on a parchment lined cookie sheet to roast without covering.  I only had the Kraft canister of parmesan which worked wonderfully.  Nothing burned and it had a nice cripsy texture.  I will make this often from now on!

text:
I made mine with cajun seasoning instead of salt, and I chopped up a couple of red potatoes and threw them in the mix as well. I actually forgot to add the parmesan cheese and parsley (oops!), but I still think it tasted great! I heated the oil in a cast-iron dutch oven on a medium-high heat and then cooked it for just a minute, and then I just put the lid on and cooked it according to the directions. Very good!!!

text:
Very good, and easy. I cut the oil down by 1/3 and added the fresh parsley halfway through cooking rather than right before broiling. I've also tried it with a pound of fresh broccoli florets instead of cauliflower, and I liked that even more; I mixed the broccoli version with an onion herb quinoa and it was amazing. Definitely a keeper, in either style.

userID:
7886824
Display Name:
bigblu2u
isPro:

1

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I added some things to this delicious recipe. I had 2 (12) oz steam in the bag broccolli and cauliflower florets and used them. I added ground cumin, garlic powder, rosemary and very thinly sliced spanish onion to the other items in the shake and bake mix. Baked at the prescribed temp UNCOVERED. Stirred at 10 minutes. At the 20 minute mark, I took it out, added some sweet mini roasted peppers I had made several days earlier, mixed, put the parmesan and parsley on top. Broiled it for 5 more minutes, took it out and squeezed 1/2 a lemon on top. The broccolli added some nice color and texture, as did the mini peppers, which added some sweetness as well. (Trick: put lemon in microwave for 10 secs to make the juices flow). Serve over brown rice or whole grain angel hair pasta.

text:
Wow! This rocks! I made it with cauliflower and broccoli and used more olive oil than the recipe called for. I also added bread crumbs to the parm cheese and mixed it all in a big bowl. Roasted it in glass dish at 400 for about 45 mins. I covered it with foil for the first 30 mins and then uncovered for the remaining time. It went great with baked flounder and brown rice. I think this recipe would be great with carrots too! Thanks for sharing..so simple and delicious!

I skipped the parsley because I didn't have fresh and I was afraid the dried would burn.  This was an awesome, simple way to prepare cauliflower.

My family loved these. I thought they were very good, but I think I wanted more of that steamed taste as opposed to roasting. My family says otherwise so I'm outnumbered for the next time I make this, which I will. I did NOT cover them while baking which is why they have that roasted taste. Delicious either way, I'll bet. Thanks for posting this recipe!

Delicious.  Simple.  Easy.  I was heavy on the garlic and the parsley.  Only had about 1/2 the parmesan on hand so also grated asiago and tiny bit of romano to compensate.  I forgot to add S&P and it didn't matter.  I cooked it in a glass meatloaf dish at 400 covered for 15 mins. mixed, 10 minutes, 10 minutes uncovered and  tossed and then 4 minutes under the broiler, turned it off and let it sit for a bit in the hot oven. So delicious.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow, just as almost everyone else has said, this is amazingly delicious. Hubby and I felt like it was a treat not a vegetable that we had to force ourselves to eat! I made half a recipe for just the two of us so I cooked it at 425 for 20 minutes then added the parmesan (no parsley) and broiled for five minutes. Make sure to grease the baking sheet or maybe try cooking on tin foil to make cleanup easier. The broiled parmesan is NOT easy to get off an ungreased pan and cooking spray was not a good substitute as I found out the hard way! LOL  We will eat this many times in the future! Thanks so much for this easy and yummy recipe. Update: I actually made this again the very next day! I used tin foil on a baking sheet and sprayed the tin foil with cooking spray before spreading the vegetables on it, worked like a charm for same taste with easier cleanup!!

text:
I followed the recipe nearly to the letter.  I added a few dashes of garlic powder and onion powder to the oil mixture, as well as the parsley.  I tossed the cauliflower in a bowl (much easier to scrape out all the yummy seasonings) and I didn't use any parmasean cheese (don't like it).  The results were fabulous!  I normally do this in the microwave with a little margarine in a gallon size zip loc bag (5-8 minutes on high).  This was divine!  Thanks!

text:
Very delicious!  However, I found it needed to be stirred every 5 minutes to keep from burning.  I used 2 tblsp. oil and didn't find it oily at all. I also added 1/4 cup water in the beginning to help it steam.  Once it evaporated, it browned nicely and after 25 minutes in the oven, I covered it with foil and let it rest on the counter 15 minutes to steam in the pan.  I will make this again for sure.

text:
This was soo good! I was making it for only myself so I used half a head of cauliflower, added WAY more garlic because I love it-probably like 5 cloves and also threw in some baby carrots. I covered it for about 20 mins then took the foil off and cooked for 10 mins more @ 375 degrees. I then added parm. cheese with some panko bread crumbs and crumbled that on top to broil for 3 mins.
It was soo filling, healthy, and tasted fabulous!! Oh and it also smelled amazing!! I will def. make this again!! :)

text:
Follow the directions and do not put a lid on the pot/pan - as someone who tried the recipe did. Lid = Mush. However, if the heat is too high, just reduce to 400 or 375 degrees and put on the top uppermost rack in the oven. Experimentation is one of the mothers of invention! I left out the parm. cheese and after it was baked enough, I added approx. 1/3 cup shredded med. cheddar and let it melt on top for about 7 minutes. Also very tasty.

text:
I would have given 5 stars, but I had to make a few changes. I didn't want to cover it because it would get mushy, I wanted it roasted, but I know from experience cooking at 450 was going to burn it.  I preheated oven to 375 and I covered my baking pan with foil and sprayed with oil,  cooked the cauliflower uncovered until it was tender and golden brown, about 30 minutes depending on how big the pieces are  and it was firm with a lovely nutty taste.

userID:

Display Name:
yyzfoodscene
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/17.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this tonight and was very impressed, after reading the many reviews I ended up changing up the method of cooking. Many people commented on that even after the hour + the cauliflower was still somewhat raw.  I put my cauliflower in an aluminium pie plate and poured chicken stock ( no sodium) to just cover the bottom and covered with foil. This created a steam that made the cauliflower cook faster, about 15-20 mins before i took it out of the oven i removed the foil and let it brown and the liquid reduce.  It was absolutely fantastic!  It has a mild nutty taste and it was not over done , it was still firm but cooked through. I grated some parm on top  and the reduced liquid became some what of an au jus  that  I spooned on top.  I was never a cauliflower eater until today, I will be making this again and again.......enjoy!

text:
This was my first time eating roasted cauliflower and it was delicious! I used the ingredients listed, mixed everything but the parsley and parmesan together on the roasting pan, and then baked it covered at 400 degrees for 20 minutes. At that point I removed the foil from the top, added the parsley and parmesan cheese and put it back in the oven for five minutes until the cheese was melted. We'll definitely be having this again!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/385165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been looking for different ways to make all the cauliflower that has mysteriously accumulated in my freezer.  Because I didn't have fresh cauliflower or garlic, I used frozen cauliflower and garlic paste.  It came out quite good.  I did not cover it up, like other users suggested, I wanted a more roasted look and flavor. The florets were firm enough to stay on the fork, but soft enough to eat easily.  The parsley was a good visual contrast.  The cheese added a little bite at the end.  It's a beautiful dish and the garlic smell is fabulous. This is great as is, or as a starting to add other ingredients!  This will be on the Thanksgiving table.

text:
Awesome recipe! I pretty much followed the directions, but I lowered the heat to 425F, kept it uncovered, cooked 25 mins. as directed then broiled for 3 mins. at 500F. Make it your own by adding different seasonings. I added a couple shakes of onion powder and Bell Pepper & Herb Rub from the Pampered Chef line. You could use any number of herbs like rosemary or tarragon, depending on what you're pairing it with. Just fabulous. Will be making this again for sure!

text:
This was a great new way to eat cauliflower.  I used three cloves of garlic which wasn't quite 2 TBS. and it was enough for us.  I also did not have fresh parsley on hand to top it off.  I covered the dish at 425 degrees for about 25 min then just sprinkled some cheese on top and broiled it on low for about 5 min.  Any hotter a temp or longer the garlic would have been burnt.  The kids weren't impressed but my husband and I loved it.

text:
All of the reviews are correct - this was fantastic! I used fresh garlic that I pressed (it was really garlicky bc I used a whole small head, but I love garlic). I did reduced the temperature to 425 degrees and left mine UNCOVERED and it roasted beautifully (my pieces of fresh cauliflower were avg., not too small). I enjoyed this just as much cold the next day. Awesome. Can't wait to make for a family party. We usually bread and fry ours, but this was much easier, healthier (I'll try two tbls of oil next time and see if I can get away with less oil) and way less messy! Thanks for such a great recipe.

text:
I wanted to like this....I REALLY did!  I LOVE Cauliflower....but this was dry and completely tasteless.  I read a lot of the reviews and decided to cover it for the first 15 minutes, then another 15 uncovered.  It was still hard - and not a "crispy goodness" hard...but an "uncooked" hard.  I left it in the oven for a little bit longer than 35 minutes, but I finally had to take it out because it was going to be totally scorched on the outside if I didn't, and that was with reducing the heat to 400 after about 25 minutes....and it was still pretty much raw in the middle.  I'll try it again - at some point....I can work around the temperature of the oven...but there is going to need to be A LOT added for flavor!

None
text:
We use cauliflower all the time now! This dish is delish!
I followed the recipe exactly the first time, and then made modifications to fit my family.
1. I do not use the bag to toss olive oil & minced garlic, it works better for me to use a large bowl.
2. A little extra garlic - my family loves garlic.
3. Covered baking dish with foil - it keeps it nice and crunchy, yet keeps it from drying out and burning. 
4. I followed others advice and kept florets uniform in size. Works wonderfully.
I will try other veggies with this great recipe!

Excellent recipe. I agree with another reviewer that the plastic bag is a bit frustrating (garlic sticks to the inside instead of the cauliflower) - might try a bowl next time. I did also cover the casserole dish and bake at 200 Celsius for 20 minutes - then uncovered, added Parmesan, and attempted to broil (Europeans don't really understand the concept of broiling, so basically just put my oven as high as it would go and selected for heat from the top only). text:
This is a fantastic recipe. It uses a rather lackluster veggie and turns into into an impressive side dish. My husband is not a fan of parmesan cheese, so I subbed it for some grated sharp white cheddar. I baked it covered for about 20 minutes (stirring once) and then broiled it uncovered for another 10 or so (stirring a few times to evenly brown it). My husband doesn't usually care for cauliflower, but even he had seconds!

This recipe was very nice.  I'm not a huge cauliflower fan, but it was very tasty.  I followed advice of others and combined the cauliflower, olive oil, and garlic in a bowl instead of a bag. text:
Roasted Garlic Cauliflower Haiku: "Nice, perky method, to dress up cauliflower. Dull veggie made good!" Chuckle all you want, but we ate this as an alternative to chips or fries alongside grilled hot dogs last night. With the lightly-browned top and satisfying seasoning of garlic, we really liked how the ingredients, and preparation, of this recipe made a typically boring vegetable more tasty. But, I find the AR recipe "Cauliflower alla Parmagiana" far superior in taste to to this, which I think is due to the use of panko sprinkled on top.

Yummy!  Just finished eating this recipe with dinner tonight and it was very tasty!  This was the first time I have eaten cauliflower prepared this way and I'm definitely a convert!  I followed the recipe as written except I kept it covered for the first 15 minutes of cooking as other reviewers have suggested and instead of measuring the parm I just sprinkled a little bit over the cauliflower.  I probably used a little less than 1/4 c.  Also, I omitted the parsley just because I didn't have any.  I really enjoyed this method of preparation.  Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
I'm only reviewing for the method of cooking, as I didn't follow the recipe ingredients (used granulated garlic instead of minced, and skipped the Parmesan entirely in order to lower the calories), but this was absolutely perfect. I cooked at 450 degrees on a metal sheet tray spritzed with non-stick spray, and pulled out at 25 minutes as directed, after stirring once partway through. The florets came out of the oven with just the tips starting to turn golden. Delicious and healthy!

userID:
3990438
Display Name:
sweet&savory
isPro:

23

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ok, when I first saw this recipe, I wasn't all that excited even after reading the ginormous list of excellent reviews.  I love cauliflower raw (and hate it steamed or cooked in general), so I thought, why do so many people love cooked cauliflower?!  But my mother in law gave me an entire forest of cauliflower (my husband and I would have been eating raw cauliflower 3x a day for a month), so I decided to try something new.  SOOOOO...from now on, if I ever cook cauliflower, it will be in this recipe!!!  It was delicious.  My husband loved it too, and he's a raw cauliflower person like me.  This is a fantastic way to cook cauliflower.  Thank you for the recipe.
Review:
Rating:
3
dateLastModified:
2010-04-13T17:21:08.223

Excellent.   I have always felt lukewarm about cauliflower and never purchased it (not enough flavor as a vegetable). I found it hard to believe that such a simple recipe added so much flavor.  I will DEFINITELY go out of  my way to buy cauliflower now.

text:
The flavor of this recipe was good, but it definately needs more spice, like hot pepper flakes. Also, it took longer to cook by about 25 minutes. Next time, I would  add the salt after the cauliflower is roasted, since too much water leaches out during cooking if it is added before roasting, hindering the carmelization of the veggies.

text:
So good! One of my favorite ways with many veggies is roasting at high heat. Cauliflower really gets luscious when roasted and browned. Used three cloves of garlic since two of them where on the skinnier side, perfect amount for me. I left out the Parmesan since I had an earlier meal that had a lot of it, so I skipped the last broiler step and simply stirred the parsley in when the cauliflower was done. Definitely though, I can see that Parmesan would be outstanding in this and will do that next time. I can't think of anything to improve this recipe.

text:
Never knew cauliflower and broccoli could taste this good!  I used a mix of califlower and broccoli.  I also added in a little bit cayenne pepper and some onion powder.  I also skipped the broiling part, as I don't think it was necessary.  After roasting for 25-30 min., I immediately put the cheese on top and then served.  Thanks, and will make again!  Update: reduce cooking time to 15 minutes my putting the cauliflower in the microwave for 3 minutes before the mixing step and oven.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/14.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I went looking at the last minute for something to do with my cauliflower other than steam it or drown it in cheese, and this was a winner.  I doubt it had much impact on the flavoring, but to save myself time I prepared it in advance. I broke up the cauliflower and put it directly into the baking dish, then mixed the garlic and olive oil together and poured it on top, mixed it up, covered it in foil, and stuck it in the fridge until I was ready to bake it.  I baked it at 350 for an hour because it was in there with the chicken and it came out too soft, but next time I will follow the directions to see if it's a little more firm.

text:
I would steam the cauliflour for a few minutes before roasting it to make sure that it softens enough.I ended up roasting it for an extra 15-20 minutes. I mixed it with the oil in a bowl instead the bag and then I added the garlic mixing it in with my hands. (I used the microplaner to mince the garlic.) like the others I covered the dish for the first 10 minutes. I really liked the dish though. I didn't find that the parm cheese added much to the dish.

text:
I like this very much (but dont' cook it in a toaster oven - it BURNS!).

I also like it better with these variations:  Add a sliced red pepper to the cauliflower.
Combine the olive oil, garlic & parsley with two chopped spring (green) onions, 1/2 tsp ginger and 3 tbsp lemon juice.  Brush this "marinade" over the veg and cook as above.  I added a thick slice-worth of toast crumbs and 1/4 cup of finely-grated Gruyere cheese to the Parmesan towards the end.

text:
LOVE IT!  This is our favorite way to make cauliflower.  We will usually make the recipe as is, but depending on our mood, we will add more or less garlic, onion powder, or grated romano cheese, or when adventurous a touch of chili powder.  We have noticed the age and freshness of fresh cauliflower matters.  Sometimes the florets seem dry and we need to add a little water to the pan or sometimes just needs to cook a bit longer.  Either way, this dish is a hit at our house.

I absolutely love this recipe!! I would give it 10 stars if I could. I have been dieting for some time now and it is very rare to find something so delicious be so good for you! I used olive oil cooking spray instead of olive oil for fewer calories, and as I had no fresh garlic, I used garlic salt with parsley flakes, and had no trouble with anything burning. It's a good thing my family also loved this, because I will be cooking it all the time!

text:
Oh, this is super easy to make. My mom loved it and my dad thinks the strong garlic flavour really suits the dish. I left out the cheese but it was still fantastic. So maybe next time, I'll do a portion with cheese and a portion without just to taste the difference. This is a really quick and easy dish to whip up especially on a lazy evening when I don't feel like using the stove top. And by the way, I cooked the cauliflower with aluminium foil cover for the first half of the time and uncovered it for the second half. After cooking, I switched off the oven and left the dish in there until dinner. It was still warm and was absolutely delicious!

This was really good.  I baked it with "Guy-approved Meatloaf" from this site, which means that they baked at 375 for about an hour.  They still weren't done quite as well as I would have liked.  I ended up broiling them for 5 minutes at the end to brown them up a bit.  I also added carrots and sprinkled some cayenne pepper over them.  The spicy went well with the sweet from the roasting.  Everyone raved.

This was very tasty and different from the ho-hum steamed vegetable.  I had a small head of cauliflower but kept the garlic the same, as I love garlic.  I just combined the oil, garlic, s&p in a dish and poured over the florets in a bowl and tossed.  I didn't bother with the cheese/broiling step at the end.  The cauliflower still had a slight nice crunch and not mushy at all.  Squeezed some lemon juice over top at the end.  This is even better cool/warm and I ate it like popcorn.  A nice way to get the veggies.

Display Name:
KarenVC

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1267690.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent!  I served it tonight with a beef fillet for the perfect dinner.  Easy to prepare and experiment with.  Like many other commenters, I used a lidded bowl rather than a plastic bag (so wasteful!) to mix the garlic and oil with the cauliflower (I was able to scrape up all the remaining oil and seasoning to put atop the cauliflower once it left the bowl).  I also added about two teaspoons of finely chopped rosemary from our garden.  I roasted at the recommended temperature and time and didn't cover the glass roasting pan.  It came out just a bit browned after 25 minutes.  Before putting under the broiler, I dusted with a bit of Italian breadcrumbs and then added the parmesan cheese.  I left for five minutes for more color.  Delicious served immediately.  Just crispy enough; so glad that I resisted the temptation to cover. My husband, who does most of the cooking in our house, was very impressed.

Display Name:
yvonne

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely don't cover the baking dish. The point is to get it soft and sweet on the inside and crunchy and caramelized and salty on the  outside, almost blackened. It becomes like veggie candy. It doesn't keep well. You need to eat it hot and crunchy out of the oven so it should be the last thing you pull out. I skip broiling by baking at 475 with lots of tossing and watching. Make a lot because it reduces down when you cook it this way. Even the very brown, very crunchy bits are delish.  This is my absolute favorite veg and I can literally eat it like candy.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

None
text:
I made this as it was intended, in an open pan. You cant roast when its in a covered casserole. Someone else pointed out that theirs was mushy when they did this. Thats because its steamed. I cooked mine in a countertop oven and just dropped it down to the bottom rack, to avoid burning. It turned out great.

This is definitely healthier that a cheese covered recipe (which I was looking for). Next time I will at least mix most of the parsley in with the garlic and oil, leaving a little to sprinkle on later. I might also try adding a little Italian seasoning to the mix as well.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made it exactly as written in my toaster oven using a Pyrex dish. It ended up a little burnt so next time I will reduce the temperature. Delicious as written! Thank you!
12/5/19 I used an eco green baking sheet in my oven, not toaster oven and I loosely covered it with aluminum foil for 10 minutes. Yep, mushy but not burnt. I uncovered for the next 10 minutes and some of  the florets were burnt. Put into a pyrex before broiling with cheese and, I love the taste but it's still not ready to serve to guests. I'm looking for the perfect cooking feedback. Thanks. 1/27/20 Oiled glass pyrex, baked at 400 for 10 minutes, turned and baked for 12 more than broiled on high with cheese for 3 minutes. Perfect! Not soggy! Not burnt! And yes, it was uncovered.

text:
I am not a regular eater of cauliflower but this recipe was fantastic. I doubled the olive oil and used minced garlic. I prepared small florets in a freezer bag with the oil, garlic, salt and pepper and let it sit for two hours. I cooked it a bit longer than the recipe calls for and added the cheese at the end, with another 10 minutes to brown it slightly. Italian flat parsley generously sprinkled over the top. Wow what a hit!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A delicious and different way to prepare cauliflower!  I used a bag of refrigerated flowerettes from Trader Joe's. I didn't use fresh garlic because I was afraid of it burning at the high temp. Instead I used garlic and onion powders (easier, too!). Put on a foil-lined cookie sheet instead of a casserole dish. Broiled only for 3 min after the fresh parsley and parmesan was added. Delicious  flavor from the parmesan, and the cauliflower browns but is not crispy and melts in your mouth.

None
text:
This was fabulous!!! To keep the garlic from burning, I did not mince or chop, but rather smashed the cloves and drizzled with a little olive oil and salt, then added halfway  through the cooking time. Cooked at 400F for 40 min to get edges crispy and browned. Seasoned with lemon pepper, sea salt, dried parsley, and a little garlic powder. Skipped the parm because we didn't have any on hand and I was too lazy to run to the store!?? Turned out terrific anyway! Thanks for sharing!

text:
This has become a favorite side dish in my household! What an easy and tasty way to incorporate cauliflower into our diets. I prepare it per the recipe, though I do the mixing in a large bowl instead of a bag (helps keep the garlic with the cauliflower instead of sticking to the side of the bag). I've also found that I can skip the broiling step at the end--it works just as well to add the Parmesan 3-5 minutes from the end time.

text:
OK it wasn't done exactly the same way, BUT WOW . . .   

. . . I microwaved a cut-up head of cauliflower first,  THEN looked for a recipe and found this one. Had no fresh garlic, parsley, or olive oil left, so I used dried parsley, garlic powder, and butter. But I did have fresh Parmesan cheese (yay!) I did not measure the add-ins, just sprinkled away, zapped it for 2 more minutes, and WOW was this delicious!  Everyone loved it and wanted more. I can't wait to re-stock my kitchen with fresh ingredients and try this cauliflower roasted in the oven.

text:
Simple, easy and delicious. Even those who really hate to spend time in the kitchen will fall in love with this quick and simple recipe. The combination of spices and cheese really brings out the flavor of the cauliflower. I followed the suggestion of others by making the cauliflower pieces as uniform as possible and bite-size. I also cooked covered with foil. Instead of adding the parmesan and parsley later, I combined all of the ingredients into the plastic bag, shook until coated and baked as directed without stirring midway. It turned out spectacular.

text:
Simply delicious!  It was a GREAT Thanksgiving side dish!  The only change I made was to cook it WITH brussels sprouts  and add a bit more oil because of the extra volume of vegetables and it was amazing.  I thought it might be too much garlic but went ahead and added what the recipe called for.  When the garlic was raw the garlic aroma was so strong but after cooking it was perfect.  I used the parmesan cheese that comes in the little tub in the deli section instead of the powdery shake-on variety--don't know if it matters but mine turned out great.  Thank you so much for this recipe!

text:
I cannot say what the author of the recipe intended in regards to covered or uncovered, (because it is not specified to cover it, I assumed not). I made this actually on a cookie sheet (I dropped my casserole and it being of advanced age it shattered). I did not cover it but spread it out and allowed it to slightly brown. My family is begging me to make it again this week, and they NEVER ask for Veggies, well with the exception of my home canned beans, but that is another story. Anyway I agree with Granny Bird and others that this is "simply the best way to cook cauliflower that I have ever had".  Thank you for posting it and sharing it!

text:
5 stars because my husband actually ate it, and he HATES cauliflower! I cut the florets as uniform as possible, only tossed it with olive oil and salt. I loosely covered with foil to get it a bit soft (i have a 1 and 1/2 year old) for about 10min. After removing the foil, I stirred and roasted for another 10-15min. I didn't have time to roast the parmesan so I just tossed it in right after it was done. If I have time the next go around I will definitely roast with the parmesan!

Very easy variation for cauliflower. I followed someone else's suggestion of baking 20 minutes at 400-degress, increasing the heat towards the end of the baking time. I found that broiling for 3 minutes was sufficient after adding the shredded parmesan -- the vegetable didn't become overcooked; the browned melted cheese was so tasty!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I prefer the 2013 recipe for Smoky Cauliflower ...drizzle florets with olive oil and a little butter, salt, tsp. of smoked paprika Toss to coat and bake uncovered in a 15-in. x 10-in. x1 in. pan for 10 minutes Stir in 2 minced garlic cloves ( or as much as you like )and bake 10-15 min. longer or until cauliflower is tender and slightly browned. Sprinkle with  a little bit of fresh minced parsley. Simple . With the florets cut small, there is no need to cook or steam them before roasting.

text:
We loved this.  To be fair I had a computer problem after finding recipe so just made it from memory.  I added a bunch of asparagus in bite sized pieces and added cajun salt and Tabasco.  I probably used more olive oil as I didn't measure.  I put it on 2 baking sheets covered with non-stick foil.  I topped it all with a cup and a half of shredded Parmesan and put in to bake at 450.  I cooked it about 15 minutes until the cheese had become brown and crusty and found the veggies perfect!!  It was WONDERFUL!!  Thanks so much!

text:
Wow. Best cauliflower ever!! I'm tired of creamy sauces drowning the cauliflower, and I bought a head of golden cauli today to try instead of plain white. 

Phenomenal. I only did half a head and wish I'd done the whole head as I fed two others as well and they wanted seconds of it. An a1 winner.

Don't cover it - it steams. Leave uncovered in middle shelf and keep an eye on it so it doesn't burn. I'm going to try again tomorrow night but use some leftover ricotta I have instead of parmesan.

text:
I am now officially addicted to roasted cauliflower!  I mix the cauliflower with chopped onion, olive oil and minced garlic in a large glass bowl, NO plastic bag.  Bake uncovered at 425 for 20 minutes, give it a stir then sprinkle some grated Parmesan cheese and put back in the oven for 10 more minutes.  No measuring anything, just add until it looks good.  I've made a batch every week since I came across this yummy recipe.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious.  Needs a little adjustment - next time I would not put the raw garlic on the cookie sheet at the beginning of the cooking process at 450 degrees.  It got way to crispy and overcooked, near bitter.   I would saut it separately on stove top while cauliflower is roasting and then sprinkle over top with the fresh parsley when done. Or I would put the raw garlic in with the roasting cauliflower when only 10 minutes left on cooking time.  Be careful of 450 degrees - start high, then reduce to 425 and watch it all the time.  It needs to get browned up to taste good.  Not steamed. Using a cookie sheets lets it brown up crispy. Other than that it's so wonderful.  I personally did not care for the parmesan cheese on top so I would offer it in a bowl for each guest to take if wanted.  Thanks you for this great recipe.
Review:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yum,  but recommend trading the bag for a mixing bowl. A lot of the garlic  and oil coat the bag, and is lost unless you scrape it out, which is tricky. Much easier to turn the florets/garlic/ oil over a few times in a mixing bowl which is then easily scraped out with a spatula. Also, you can't reuse that sealable bag, so it is not environment-friendly.
I mixed my parmesean with Panko crumbs to give this a crispy topping. Lower heat for sure: 375-400 until tender.

Just made this and both my husband (who is not a big veggie eater) and my toddler loved it.  I decreased the heat to 400 degrees and cooked for the full 25 minutes.  I did not cover.  I used fresh garlic (a whole bulb for a large head of cauliflower; we are huge garlic lovers).  After pouring it into the casserole dish, I sprinkled with a little sea salt and garlic powder. text:
Fantastic!! Love this recipe and its so easy to tweak for variety. I've used several kinds if cheese, and my favorite is Aged Dutch. I also like to add red pepper flakes for a little kick. AND I've tried some of those fancy flavored olive oils, and find the garlic is the best. The truffle is really interesting, if you like that. My mother who has always shunned cauliflower likes this recipe. Score!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious! I used frozen cauliflower, which required time adjustments. For frozen cauliflower, steam for 3-4 minutes until just tender but not fully thawed, and per recipe instructions mix with olive oil and garlic (I didn't have parsley so I didn't use it) and put in oven on 450 degrees. Cook time will be less than if you'd used raw cauliflower; I did 10 minutes before adding my parmesan, and left it for 3-4 more minutes. It was perfect - and tasted amazing! Great, quick way to make a tasty and healthy side dish.

country:
None
text:
I am not a cauliflower person, but this is good!
I read comments before I made this, and I separated the Cauliflower and put in my casserole dish, mixed everything together (except the cheese) and poured it over the cauliflower  in the casserole dish, stirring to make sure it is evenly coated. I didn't need to grease the pan by doing it  this way. I didn't add the bread crumbs until halfway thru the baking time, this worked out great, the flavors from all the ingredients blended in well before adding the breadcrumbs.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Really enjoyed this recipe! 
I did make a few tweaks based on some other reviews I read. I cooked it at 400 instead of 450, and covered it for about 10 minutes, I then uncovered it, added the Parmesan and some breadcrumbs and broiled it for another 10 minutes.
I also did not have parsley so I used dried basil and chives.
Over all this turned out really well, the cauliflower was still crisp which I enjoyed. My brother who doesn't normally like cauliflower loved it, he said it was like "cauliflower alfredo" (minus the cream).

text:
VERY DELICIOUS RECIPE!  Added 1 crown of broccoli.  Omitted parmesan.  Used 1 tsp. sea salt & 1/2 tsp. coarse ground black pepper.  Baked at 425 on a cookie sheet sprayed with cooking oil for 20 minutes.  Sprinkled with dried parsley and baked another 5 minutes, and it was perfect!  No need to broil; it browned on bake.  Note:  I used 8 cloves of fresh minced garlic to get a measurement of 2 tbsp.

city:

country:

text:
THis was yummy, and I gave it the benefit of the doubt with 5 stars - but I would take half a star off because I think the instructions could have been a bit clearer. It says to put this in a large baking dish, and I used a 2 quart casserole dish - but I think it should have recommended a 9x13 pan so the cauliflower was basically in a single layer (I looked at the video after the fact and that is what they used). It browns up more evenly that way. Also, whenever I try to roast vegetables with minced garlic, my garlic always burns. This may be due to the fact that I usually go a little light on the oil, maybe it needs all that oil to keep it moist?
Anyway, this was very good and easy to throw together on a weeknight. What more do you need?

Love this recipe, my kids hated cauliflower! NOT ANY MORE! roasting it gives it a great sweet flavor, every time I make it they gobble it up. I usually skip the parmisan and parley, I just dabble a little bit of olive oil some fresh garlic, a little salt and pepper and it comes out just as good. Display Name:
Anne Marie

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Unlike other reviewers I did not cover the pan as I was going for a more roasted vs steamed texture, but I did use a high sided ceramic casserole dish and I think this helped it somewhat from burning. My only change from the recipe was that I used about one cup of freshly grated parmesan, I had only dried parsley so I used about two tablespoons of this, and I added about half a teaspoon of Tony Chachere's instead of the regular salt to give it a little spice. It was fantastic! Even my kids ate it. I had prepped it for my husband to put in the oven, and when I came back home I could not believe how good it smelled, too. No stinky steamed cauliflower smell here! Super easy and my new favorite recipe for cauliflower.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Easy, delicious, and healthy!  I didn't use quite as much olive oil, mostly because  ran out!  I recommend following directions and using a casserole dish instead of a deep cookie sheet (which I used to do).  It's much easier to stir in a casserole dish.

Also, I didn't put mine in the broiler.  I just threw some foil on top, left it in the oven,and turned off the over.  The cheese and parsley got all melty while I finished preparing the rest of dinner.

It was good leftover too!  I snacked on a few cold pieces this morning.  Nom nom!

text:
I'm not generally a big fan of cauliflower unless it's been mashed to mush. While this did not do much to improve the texture of cauliflower, it did add some fabulous flavor to an otherwise bland vegetable. I included some fresh basil and a pinch or two of oregano. My mother, who is even less a fan of cauliflower than I am, greatly enjoyed it; she even complimented me on it! 

"This cauliflower is delicious! How did you make it?"
"Why, thank you, I just threw some- Wait, what?!"

text:
THE BEST!!..OMG this was so good..The perfect way to serve this vegetable which is so bland tasting to me.. I followed the instructions just like the video.. Except I added a little more twist on it. I did sprinkle some black pepper over the cauliflower with also a little more garlic powder..I then sprinkled dry Parmesan cheese over it, baked it for 20 minutes @ 450 degrees.. then I took it out sprinkled pieced of pepper jack over the florets put it in the over on broil.. when it melted I then sprinkled the diced parsley on it put it back in the broiler for 45seconds then it was ready to serve.

userID:
4991710
Display Name:
tellison74
isPro:

3

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a success all the way around at my house, all 3 of my guys liked it very well. I made a few changes. Added 3 slices of bacon, which I cooked lightly and cut up. Used only 2T olive oil and 1T bacon grease, tossed oils with cauliflower in the dish I was baking it in, salted generously and put a little pepper on it, cooked at 425 for 15 minutes, then stirred and added the garlic (to keep it from burning per other reviews) and the bacon. Covered and cooked another 20 minutes, removed from oven, added the parmesan and recovered and let it sit on the stovetop while the rest of the meal finished cooking. The cauliflower was perfectly cooked with no crunch left, just the way we like it, and the flavor was awesome. Will make this again for sure!

text:
I have made this recipe a few times, and it's a great way to add flavor and color to cauliflower. I added the Parmesan cheese and sprinkled on dried parsley (didn't have fresh on hand), but I didn't have to use the broiler after baking. The cauliflower was beautifully browned after the baking. I generally make a couple of heads on a large cookie sheet, and then freeze them in meal-sized portions. When I use them for a meal, I simply have to thaw and re-warm them in the microwave.

This was my first time roasting cauliflower and it was really delicious. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I give this 5 stars without actually knowing . . . I made this because I normally don't like cauliflower, but we had a head of it from our CSA, and I thought I might find a way I like to eat it. I had to take my daughter to girl scouts, and told my husband to go ahead and eat some of it meanwhile. When I got home, it was gone. I didn't even get to taste it. So my review is based on his reaction. I didn't use a plastic bag - I don't like plastic or wasting plastic bags this way, so I just mixed in a bowl. I could have just mixed it in the pan and not had to wash a bowl. Also, I used a larger glass dish to bake it in rather than a casserole, so I could spread it out to avoid burning as others suggested. I didn't change the recipe (except I didn't have any parsley) and I didn't cover it, but I always bake for less than recommended time because our oven seems to run hot. This was very easy to make and clean up. Now if I had only gotten to try it!

I have been making roasted cauliflower for ages.  On a lark, I tried this recipe.  Fantastic.  Truly the best cauliflower I've ever eaten.   I think next time I will cut the garlic by 25%, but that's just because we like our garlic flavor to be subtle.   I think the Parmesan cheese makes this recipe, although we used less because we are watching our cheese intake.

text:
WOW. I hate cauliflower...or did until just now! My changes were: coarse grey sea salt, freshly minced garlic, covered with foil and baked for 20min, then broiled on high for 5min. 
I am giving 5 stars because it is so easy and could be versatile (balsamic vinegar comes to mind) if one chose.
I served with curried brown rice and Parmesan broiled squash slices. Thank you!

text:
Best cauliflower Ive ever had! & I NEVER buy cauliflower!  Had a friend give me one. You can depend on ALLRecipes.com to supply an assortment & tasty ways to prepare such a lovely dish as this!  (I Love using the INGREDIENTS tool to "salvage" whatever you have on hand in your fridge) Like someone mentioned: "This is now my favorite way to prepare cauliflower" AND-->  "Add as much garlic as you like! Roast cauliflower only just 'til slightly soft. Don't overcook"  The one thing I did differently (I like to prep ahead) was to marinade all, all afternoon: same ingredients...just extra EVO & added oregano as well, to zip bag.  Thought this was a marvelous dish. Added Xtra cheese...did not broil, just let sit in oven for 10 mins. Even after dinner was over, couldn't resist the urge to pick the crusty Parmesan bits...soooo good w/ the cauliflower! :)  yum!! I've done a 180 on cauliflower- This recipe is Keeper!

text:
Mmmmm. This was SO good! I have been craving cauliflower lately. Not sure why, but after tasting this, I am glad I have. :) To speed prep, I purchased a small bag of cauliflower florets. I proceeded as directed, but instead of roasting at 450 degrees, I roasted (on a shallow cookie sheet) at 400 degrees for 25 minutes. My only suggested change (for next time!) would be to decrease the amount of Parmesan cheese called for... there was too much of it for my taste. I'm also not sure I'd use the parsley either (it didn't add any oomph, IMHO). Other than these two very minor changes, this recipe is perfect as is. I have now found a new way to enjoy one of my favorite veggies! Thanks SHELLERY. :-)

text:
Honestly, I was disappointed with this recipe...especially based on all of the reviews. I followed the recipe except for adding some paprika, onion powder, and some extra garlic. Not too crazy, right?! The result, however, was that the result was too dry and crunchy. I am not sure if that is the intended result, but I don't care for my vegetables to be al dente. I will try this again because I believe it has potential. However, next time I will steam it first briefly for 10 minutes, add some melted butter, then place it in the oven for about 20-25 minutes. We'll see what happens...

I tossed in some parsley and rosemary, and omitted the Parmesan (I didn't have any on hand). Because I didn't have any tin foil handy, I baked in an 8x8 uncovered for about 30 minutes, and the firmness of the cauliflower was just about perfect. Already since I made this for the first time four nights ago, I've made it again twice. It was delicious with couscous.

text:
This recipe was decent. I love how the texture came out after following others' advice to cover the dish with foil and cook at 400 degrees, but salt to taste to me usually means just a bit of salt and I had to add a lot. Admittedly, I use kosher salt, so maybe I needed more in the first place, but after much salt adjusting plus added garlic salt and cayenne, then it was good, but not great. I will try this again. My advice is to taste this a couple times before serving, and you'll be good to go. Thanks for the recipe.

Display Name:
Crystaline

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was very good but slightly bland for me. I eat a lot of Indian food and made the following changes. After baking the cauliflower, I added 1 teaspoon of Corriander Cumin Powder, 1/2 teaspoon of Garam Masala (used in most Indian dishes), 1/3 teaspoon Degi Mirch ( hot red chilli powder) and 1/3 teaspoon of Turmeric. (All these spices are easily available at all Indian stores- MTR brand and you can add more/less to your taste). Toss till the spices are evenly spread, ganish with fresh corriander leaves and serve over steamed rice. I even added 3 medium sized potatoes chopped in the same dish with the cauliflower. Tasted like restuarant style Aloo Gobi (Cauliflower with potatoes).

text:
This is the best way to prepare cauliflower - fresh or frozen.  I skipped greasing the pan first, and also putting the ingredients in a bag.  I just placed the cauliflower in the pan and drizzled the oil and garlic over top and stirred to coat.  I covered and baked for 20 min, then did the broiling step.  I also added two strips of bacon, cooked and crumbled with the cheese.  Thank you for this recipe!

userID:
2318925
Display Name:
PattyQ

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2307234.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was so easy to make and so tasty that it is a winner! I was very fortunate to ahve purchased a "mistery Box" of fresh from the farm veggies in San Francisco, and among the fresh produce, was a whole cauliflower.  I used the outer leaves with collards on a sourthern dishe, but the winner was the cauliflower with the roasted garlic! You have to be careful that the garlic does not burn since we have all experienced the nasty taste of overdone/burned garlic. The timing on this recipe is very crucial to get the right roasty taste of the garlics. Between my hubby and I we ate a whole cauliflower... and we are on a diet!  I figure, that without the olive oil (not much f=for the whole dish) and the grease (margerine) in preparing the baking pan, I would not have added more than a couple of Weightwatcher's points!  Plus I served it with brolied halibut (no fat added, only herbs) and a heirloom  tomatoes with basil (no oil added). A perfect recipe for those on a diet and those indulging on just good food without coutning points or calories! A delicious low fat content dish!! Thank you for sharing!
PQ

text:
A good and different way to serve cauliflower. I used some of the Bistro mozzarella with basil and sundried tomato just because I had it on hand in addition to the Parmesan, and it was complimentary to the cauliflower. Be careful not to let the cauliflower get too soft, or the flavor will change too much and become too strong. This was better fresh than re-heated.
